fields.description:
Some customer development work flows will require the use of a large number of repositories, such as creating one repo per module. This has been seen with some customers high as 20 to 50 repos in a single plan.

The behaviour for the "quiet period", or timeout between the last commit and the start of the build, is incorporated in to the logic of the repo, so when there is a large number of repos this can delay the start of the build by a multiple of the quiet period for each repo.  (After the delay, the build will continue as expected.)

Modify the handling of the quiet period to either be plan based, or, in the presence of more than one repo, provide an upper limit.
fields.summary: Improve the handling of the "quiet period" when multiple repos are included in a single build plan.

fields.description: I imagine this would be similar to the existing hipchat integration.
fields.summary: Add Slack (slack.com) as a notification option

fields.description:
Say there is a deployment environment with a Scheduled trigger to run once an hour.  Version 1.0 is currently deployed.  When the trigger executes, if Version 1.0 is the latest available version, it shouldn't actually execute the deployment because it is just redeploying the same thing that is already deployed in the environment.

Having a an checkbox option to enable this would be desirable ("Don't deploy if latest version matches version currently deployed").
fields.summary: Scheduled deployments should only run if the latest version is different than what is actually deployed in that environment

fields.description:
In the [stash API for build updates|https://developer.atlassian.com/stash/docs/3.0.1/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html], there is an option to display "in progress" state that we use with Jenkins and Bitbucket Server/Stash faithfully displayed that state in Pull Requests. We were all happy.
Now that we've transitioned to Bamboo, we miss this state update. Please consider providing this state transition to Bitbucket Server/Stash when a build starts in Bamboo?
fields.summary: Update Bitbucket Server with "build in progress" state

fields.description:
Hi Team,

I would like to raise a improvement request, in order to have multi-threading in the agent sides.

Bellow is an example, on where we could improve a task to become 3 times faster, if this feature would be in place:

We have several child plans that run in parallel, triggered by a parent plan.
Each one of this plans have several stages and each stage as 1 or more jobs.
Some of the jobs of the plan are shared by the same SERVER agent. Others are belonging to different REMOTE agents.
When the plans start their execution (3 plans in parallel), there will be only 1 thread running at a time, meaning, Bamboo will "jump" between the 3 child plans, and execute 1 task at a time, for the stages/jobs that are sharing the same SERVER agent.

If the agent could execute multiple tasks in parallel, even when they are deployed in the same agent, we could make things work faster.

Keep up with the great work!

Cheers,
Ricardo Gato
fields.summary: Multhithreading in Bamboo, on the Agent Side

fields.description:
I am trying to work around the limitation of running tests during a deployment plan. Ideally Bamboo would just support running tests and displaying the results on the results page (same as build plans). However since that doesn't appear to be a priority... I wrote a plugin which extends the NUnit Runner task so that it can be used in a deployment plan. 

The problem is that the deployment result page is not extendable via a UI plugin, as the viewDeploymentResult templates do not render any UI plugin modules. So there isn't any way for me display the test results... If you would expose a section for web items or web modules, then I could display the test results on a failed deployment page.
fields.summary: Allow UI Plugins on Deployment Results Page

fields.description:
Dear Madam, Sir,

We are very satisfied with the new Bamboo and its release management from JIRA and deploying from  repository trunk or branches.
However, we would like to be able to couple this functionnalies with Maven.
Indeed, to trigger a release build, we have two dependent plans. One to generate our artifacts and one to build the Webapp, we would like to be able to :
* Use the version declared in JIRA to update Maven's Pom
* Use the adequate dependencies generated by the first build
* Easily rollback to previous status

fields.description:
It would be useful to be able to treat a failed task as a warning or notification for example in the event that say a manual fix is applied or known bad data was supplied and should be ignored.  So that when a plan fails the failed task can be noted but the rest of the plan can be manually continued from where it left off without having to restart from the beginning or manually disable steps or tasks to effectively restart where the plan left off.

This would work in the same way that the rerun failed tasks option does.
fields.summary: Ability to treat a failed task as a warning and continue the plan from after the point of failure

Requests that authenticate using OAuth, Basic Auth, or don't authenticate at all do not need to be protected from CSRF attacks.

thanks!

fields.description:
Given this {{pom.xml}} in maven project.
{code}
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
		 xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
		 xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0
                      http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
	<modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

	<parent>
		<groupId>myGroup</groupId>
		<artifactId>parent</artifactId>
		<version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
	</parent>

	<artifactId>child</artifactId>
	<version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>

	<dependencies>
		<dependency>
			<groupId>myGroup</groupId>
			<artifactId>common</artifactId>
			<version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
		</dependency>
	</dependencies>
</project>
{code}

As for now the task will only consider *common* as the dependency of *child*. It would be great if the task will take *parent* as its dependency as if it changes, the child should take effect as well.
fields.summary: Maven Dependencies Processor should recognise dependency on parent POM

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce
# Create a stage with a name that uses at least one 4-byte UTF-8 character (e.g. '𩸽'). Any description is fine.
# Attempt to create a job with any name/description.

h3. Expected result
Job is created successfully.

h3. Actual result
When clicking the "Create Job" button, nothing will happen (the dialog won't even go away, but no error is shown).

The logs will contain the following error:
{noformat}
ERROR [http-bio-8085-exec-9] [FieldErrorUsageVerifier] CreateJob: unreported field errors: existingStage : [null]
{noformat}

[4-byte UTF-8 characters|http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/utf8.htm] are less rare than you might think. For example, the [Emoji|http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emoji#In_the_Unicode_standard] characters are all 4 bytes, which are being used more commonly with Emoji input methods supplied by default in modern desktop & mobile operating systems. 💩
fields.summary: Cannot add jobs to a stage with a name containing 4-byte UTF-8 characters

fields.description:
In Bamboo v4, the Completed column on the History tab for a plan would show the time the plan completed in a hour/date format. In version 5.2, it now shows it as X hours/days ago, meaning you have to do math to figure out when the plan completed on a given day. 

Can we get an option to switch this back to the old way? We find it really useful to go back and see when the plans were run/completed.

I've added a picture of the two formats
fields.summary: Allow date format change for Completed column in plan history

fields.description:
Here's how to reproduce:

1. Create Plan A that has two stages. One job in Stage 1 creates a shared artifact, another job in Stage 2 downloads the artifact using the Artifact download task.

2. Clone Plan A into Plan B. 

3. To make sure Stage 2 of Plan B uses artifacts from Plan B and not from Plan A, edit the artifacts downloaded by the Artifact download task. Change source plan from Plan A to Plan B. The contents of the Artifact name combo box stays the same (which kind of makes sense, because the plan is a clone), so just hit Save.

4. Run Plan B. Stage 2 of Plan B does not start to execute displaying a message: "Job has not yet been queued. Waiting for prior stages to complete", while the previous stage has already completed. The build hangs. Stop the build to see an error saying "Unable to find an artifact definition for name: <your artifact name here>", while the artifact is clearly there, possible to download from Stage 1 job's Artifacts tab.

5. Further builds of the plan also result in the same error.

The current workaround to fix Plan B definition is to first change the plan from which the artifact is to be downloaded, hit Save. Then again, edit the artifact download task parameteres and choose the actual artifact to download, hit Save. It looks like the artifact name combo box is not properly refreshed when changing the source plan.

Another possible issue with the Artifact name combo box not refreshing properly is that when one changes the source plan and hit Save, the downloader will get all the artifacts and not the one that was indicated in the combo box when hitting Save.
fields.summary: A bug in Artifact download task configuration UI can lead to build hanging for not apparent reason

fields.description:
*Problem:*
a user with 'Restricted Admin' Global Permission (the highest OnDemand user permission) can't see all Build Plans. https://<instance>/builds/allPlans.action

*Cause:*
'Restricted Admin' permission on Bamboo is not the highest permission level and doesn't allow browsing and administration of all projects, despite the documentation [Bamboo permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Bamboo+permissions], says it does.
The permission 'Admin' is not available on OnDemand. (documentation should be updated on these two items if this is in fact not a bug)

*Details:*
Bamboo has the following default Global Permissions setup (as seen with sysadmin user) :
!bamboo_default_sysadmin_global_permissions.jpeg|thumbnail!

but non-sysadmin admins on OnDemand can only change:
!bamboo_default_global_permissions.jpeg|thumbnail!

*The confusion:*
When [Configuring a plan's permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+a+plan's+permissions] there is a message that says:
* *Note:*
Users with the global 'admin' permission have all of the above permissions for this plan.

That 'admin' permission is not reachable to OnDemand so you might think that the 'admin' is really the 'global admin' when actually is a 'restricted admin'.

*Ideas:*
* remove the Note on OnDemand or clarify that global 'admin' is not available
* enable browsing and administration of all plans with 'Restricted Admin' privileges for OnDemand instances.
* Update documentation: [Granting global permissions to users or groups|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Granting+global+permissions+to+users+or+groups] and [Bamboo permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AOD/Bamboo+permissions] to display accurate information for OnDemand.

*Workaround:*
Bulk edit all plans to grant group Administrators the Admin Permission:
* ask atlassian support to do so or request every Plan owner to do so by using: <instance>.jira.com/builds/admin/chooseBuildsToBulkEditPermissions.action
fields.summary: Bamboo Restricted Admin Permission doesn't give all plan permissions

fields.description:
Almost at the point of moving away from Bamboo. When we build a maven WAR for example it is publish as *.war. so any *.war is shared and can be defined any access from the deployment project. This makes NO sense. 

If you are building a WAR file it is a simple task for bamboo to locate the file name, e.g. wps-1.2.1-872ce1d-666.war and automatically link this name to the deployment project as a variable. Then when defining the deployment plan we can for example use the variable in the tomcat plugin deployment WAR specification.. 

It seems to me to be no point in publishing *.WAR and then not being able to simply link this to the deployment project.

Yes there might be some hacks... things that can be done to work around this, but bamboo should be able to do this out of the box.
fields.summary: Simplify Build to Deployment artifact resolution

fields.description:
We use a fully automated process to "refresh" our farm of linux build agents.  This includes a full tear-down of the filesystem and binaries, and re-installing all build tools, JDKs, etc.  This ensures that individual jobs and plans don't degrade the system overtime.

We keep the Agent name and ID the same for historical reporting, but would like means to purge the existing capabilities from our process.  This allows us to retire old capabilities/versions without the need to manually click, and confirm, dozens of individual capabilities on ten's of agents. 

A DELETE call to a REST URL for each agent's ID would be amazing useful for our support of commodity agents.
fields.summary: Expose ability to delete/remove agent capabilities via REST API

Use picker for creating a new plan branch (instead of the list of checkboxes)

fields.description:
Bamboo detects that a plan branch is related to a Jira Issue using the branch name, but that issue is not included in the Jira Issues list on the branch summary page.  Therefore, the Jira issue knows nothing of the plan branch.

This seems minor, because commits on the branch usually have the Jira issue in them, so the plan will usually pick up the Jira issue later.  But this doesn't happen for plan branches that are created and only run once (no code changes detected in the first build).

See the attached screenshot.  The branch is obviously related to a Jira issue.  But the list of issues is empty.
fields.summary: Branch Issues should include Branch Name

fields.description:
h4. Problem
The currently widely used IPv4 address pool is close to exhaustion: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion]. IPv6 is around already for a while, however parts of our products may (and do) break.

h4. Requirement
- Add IPv6 tests for products and clarify it being supported for all parts of the products (external system connectivity, applinks, self-naming, reverse-proxying, etc).
- Update the supported platforms documentation and explicitly specify IPv6 to be supported to avoid confusion and give support a reference point.
fields.summary: Support IPv6

fields.description:
Currently Deployments don't get expired, so historic binaries (artifacts, etc) might consume a lot of disk space over time. 

These things are only deleted if the release is manually deleted, but customers might want to know what was in a historic release (commits, issues, etc) without keeping the binaries.
fields.summary: Implement Deployment Expiry

fields.description:
Some customers have security concern in sharing email to Gravatar. This feature is enabled by default, and it could cause some issue if the email was shared without any knowledge by Administrator.

It would be great if we could disable it by default and enable if the administrator aware of the security concern.
fields.summary: Disable Gravatar on default setting

fields.description:
It looks like sessions are created in com.atlassian.bamboo.rest using Bamboo's own Random package which calls Java's random instead of Atlassian secure random https://extranet.atlassian.com/display/DEV/Using+atlassian-secure-random

Please replace.
fields.summary: REST DefaultSessionManager uses weak random

fields.description:
The restricted admin is not actually enabled but the UI looks like its enabled. It does not enable until you edit and save it withe the checkbox checked.

When you uncheck it and save it, it still shows as checked in the read only.
fields.summary: Restricted Admin Checkbox shows as checked when its not

fields.description:
Bamboo SEN: SEN-2260431

We were wondering how the connection of the deployed artifacts works. From other tickets I understand that the following directory contans the deployed artifacts. 

/opt/bamboo/bamboo-home/artifacts/globalStorage

1. If I want to free up some space on the hard disk would I caurse any problems if I was to remove artifacts which are no longer deployed.

2. If one release is deployed to more that one deployment here would we have just have one directory containg the artifacts shared acrossed the deployments ?
fields.summary: What happens in teh globalStorage directory in Bamboo.

fields.description: JIRA has added support for local user timezones. Bamboo should provide the same support.
fields.summary: Support local user timezones

fields.description:
We need a bamboo variable that holds plan name. 
The current bamboo.buildPlanName = "ProjectName - PlanName"
Can we have a variable like bamboo.buildPlanNameShort = PlanName
fields.summary: Bamboo Variable : buildPlanNameShort

fields.description: This is the same issue as BAM-12986, this time in Bamboo 5.3 (started via bin/start-bamboo.sh).
fields.summary: Filtering by label fails with Unicode labels

fields.description: After upgrading bamboo 5.1 to 5.3, when I try to deploy releases created before the upgrade they now fail because the deploys depend on the meta data from the build that the release was created from. The logs show that the bamboo variables that were set in the customized build are no longer set. When I go into the build details and look at the meta data tab I can see  that the missing variables in question are indeed overridden with the expected values. I am not sure why this is happening because I don't know how bamboo pulls the meta data from builds into releases. When i upgraded I followed these steps https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Moving+your+Bamboo+data+to+a+different+database
fields.summary: Meta data from release build missing after 5.3 upgrade

I think this limitation does not fit in with the way we want to people to be using this feature.  I also think its unnecessary.  

Users will still need the create plan permission, so it wont be wide opening.

fields.summary: Design Issue with Hide Button in Bamboo Result

fields.description:
We have lots of projects, hundreds, and the current default for cleaning the working directory after a job completes is unchecked.  This causes us a disk space issue, since jobs run randomly eventually on every local build agent.  A job that takes the current default value to NOT clean the working directory eventually takes up space equal to size of their checkout directory times the number of local agents.

We have to go through and uncheck this option behind project teams on build jobs.  It would be nice to have an admin setting that controls what the default value of this checkbox is for new jobs.
fields.summary: Ability to change default for Clean Working Directory checkbox

fields.summary: Threads keep growing if requested repositories are not available due to permission restrictions

fields.description:
When I manually create a branch build for a plan, the _Do not clean up this plan branch automatically_ flag is set by default. While this is nice for long running branches not changing very often, it is a PITA for a heavy traffic plan where devs quickly create a branch build on their own for various reasons. Even if their issue branches would match the automatic branch expression, they are not cleaned up and all the artifacts stay on the server forever until a human bot runs through the list of branches and cleans them up manually.

Instead I suggest to change the default of the flag the other way around: it is unchecked by default. So branches matching the branch expression are cleaned up properly after X days regardless whether they are created manually or picked up by the change detection. Using a branch name not matching the expression still would prevent the cleanup, even with the flag unchecked.
fields.summary: Manually created branches should be cleaned up by default

fields.description: Currently plan branches do not show up under plans for the Bulk action->Run Manual build and it's not possible to select different/specific branches to run at once.

fields.description:
To reproduce:
# cancel your bdog oauth token in bamboo
# go to a jdog issue with an associated build (e.g. https://jdog.jira-dev.com/browse/FUSE-803 )
# try to view the build. You will get asked to do the login dance
# try to do the login dance. BUG: bdog does not redirect back to JIRA and does not set the necessary oauth token.
fields.summary: OD Oauth dance doesn't work

fields.description: Please consider allowing a user to create and configure deploy variables with "type" (boolean, string, etc) and "UI Model" (multi-select combo, combo, radio, checkbox, etc) with data source selection (to be able to select a released build etc) and customized (html-formatted?) descriptions. This would allow us huge flexibility in our ability to customize deployment and minimize environment proliferation.
fields.summary: Rich data types for variables

fields.description:
We have a maven plugin that is run during our build process, that determines if the currently-building product has already been released with the current version number.

For example, if we have released product-1.0.0 (ie. a tag exists, possibly produced by build #123), and the current build (#124, or higher) is going to produce another product-1.0.0 artifact, we would like this build to stop.

Currently, we cannot determine a way to have our build stop at this point, without having the build also fail and report this failure via email to the development team.

We have configured our build plan to only listen for VCS changes to this particular repository/subproject before starting the build, but we have 3 branches for this project, and when making small configuration changes, occasionally this will trigger a build before we have updated the version number to the next development release.

We would like a way, either via a task, shell script, maven plugin, etc. to either:

1) Define a return code that, when examined by Bamboo, will cause the build to stop without failing, or:

2) Specify for a particular task (shell script, Maven process, etc.) that its failure should not cause a build failure, but rather just stop the build, as the build is unnecessary.

Here is a detailed example for what we're experiencing:

For a core dependency, the 'patch' branch is set to 1.2.2, and our 'major' branch is set to 2.0.0. We release a product that depends on the major version of this core dependency, thus "releasing" the 2.0.0 version of the dependency, creating a tag, "dependency-2.0.0".

We would now like to update our 'patch' branch to be version 2.0.0, since any of our products that are depending on the patch version should be using 2.0.0 also, instead of the 1.2.2 version. But, we also don't want to update our 'patch' branch to 2.0.1 yet, since if we quickly perform a patch release of our main product, we don't want to create an "empty" dependency-2.0.1 tag/release that has no changes. However, updating our patch branch to version 2.0.0 triggers a build, which is stopped by our maven plugin that detects the existence of tag dependency-2.0.0.
fields.summary: Stop build without Failing

fields.description:
We use the git-flow workflow. When a feature branch is created and a commit is made, Bamboo detects it and creates a plan branch for it. That works great. Unfortunately, when the feature branch is merged into its upstream and deleted, the corresponding plan branch stays in Bamboo. When Bamboo tries to check for changes in that branch, an error generated.

It would be great if Stash notified Bamboo when a branch is deleted so Bamboo can delete the corresponding plan branch.
fields.summary: Deleting a branch in Stash should delete the corresponding plan branch in Bamboo

fields.description:
Can we have project scoped variable.
UseCase : 
3 bamboo projects : Development, Integration, production having 25 plans each. We want to clone a Development plan to integration. To refer to source repository URL, we have a path variable which can be set at project level. branch.name = {Development/Integration}
Development : abc.com/source/{branch.name}/java/project1
abc.com/source/{branch.name}/java/project2
abc.com/source/{branch.name}/java/project3

fields.description:
Hey,

Bamboo allows restricting the IP addresses from which triggers are allowed to be sent but does not allow subnet masks to be specified (GitHub as example would use 192.30.252.0/22) which could be useful for environments in which huge amounts of servers (or virtual machines) are able to trigger a build.
fields.summary: Add support for subnet masks in build triggers

fields.description:
In order to fix some glaring omissions in the bamboo product, I want to create some plugins. 

However, the docs only have api up to 5.1: https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Bamboo+API+Changes+by+Version

The Developer Guide was last updated in 2012: https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Bamboo+Plugin+Guide

The example code in BitBucket was last updated in 2012: https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Bamboo+Tasks+API
(points to http://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo-sdk-examples). This page says that repo will always be supporting the latest version, but clearly it's not. 

I am at a loss here. There is a catastrophic amount of missing functionality, and no way for anybody to add it. What's going on with this product? Is it a dead tool?
fields.summary: Documentation and SDK examples not up-to-date

fields.description:
Currently in the Administration section if you view JDKs you can then select a JDK and view all associated Jobs that depend on that particular JDK.

Though it doesn't list any deployment projects that have environment tasks that may as well depend on that JDK or any other capabilities as well.

We are attempting to clean up all the listed JDKs in the system and realized that the Deployment Plans had dependencies on a JDK even though the Admin section has none listed.
fields.summary: Bamboo Administration JDKs doesn't show Deployment Environment dependent tasks

fields.description:
{panel}
(i) Please note that this bug doesn't have any major impact on your instance (i.e. it _doesn't_ make your instance freeze or become _unusable_).
{panel}

h3. Summary

When you delete a plan, Bamboo actually marks it and its plan branches for deletion as opposed to performing the operation right away. A daily task is run to perform the removal of plans in that state later in the day.

This bug is about an inconsistency that happens in the database while marking "Plans" and its "Plan Branches" for deletion. The bug is that sometimes the "Plan" is marked for deletion but it children "Plan Branches" are not.

When the daily tasks is run, Bamboo fails to remove that plan (or perhaps this could block deletion of other plans as well as the one with the inconsistency).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
The problem happens intermittently and we don't have the steps to reproduce it.

h3. Expected Results
It is expected that there is no inconsistency while marking plans for deletion.

h3. Actual Results

_Atlassian internal note: Seen on CBAC (5.4-m1 build 4201 - 24 Dec 13)_

h3.Workaround
{panel}
(i) Before going through the workaround below, please note that you *must* perform a _valid backup_ of your Bamboo instance. If you are unsure about how to do so, please refer to our documentation: [Exporting data for backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/exporting-data-for-backup-289277255.html]
{panel}

After [backing up your instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/exporting-data-for-backup-289277255.html], there are 2 approaches to solving this issue:

*Approach 1*
You can undelete the conflicted Plans by running a SQL query. These plans will then show up in the UI. After that you can proceed to deleting them again using the Bamboo UI. To show these plans again in the UI, run the query below:
{code}
update build set marked_for_deletion = 'false' where build_id in (select master.build_id from build master, build child where master.marked_for_deletion = 'true' and child.marked_for_deletion = 'false' and child.master_id = master.build_id)
{code}

*Approach 2*
Alternatively of course you can mark the conflicting plan branches as deletable with the following SQL query. We don't really prefer this option of marking things deletable through SQL statements:
{code}
update build set marked_for_deletion = 'true' where build_id in (select child.build_id from build master, build child where master.marked_for_deletion = 'true' and child.marked_for_deletion = 'false' and child.master_id = master.build_id)
{code}

*Side note: different DB servers might require different queries*
Note that the above queries are for PostgreSQL and need to be adapted to MySQL. For example, this is the latest query that should be run in a MySQL DB:
{code:SQL}update build 
set marked_for_deletion=true 
where build_id in (select child.build_id 
from (select * from build) as master, (select * from build) as child 
where master.marked_for_deletion=true and child.marked_for_deletion=false and child.master_id=master.build_id);{code}
fields.summary: Branches not marked for deletion when master plan/job is - causes deletion to fail

fields.description:
When there is a merge in git the comment mentions the branch name. Bamboo would then show it on its dashboard like this
{code}
Code Changes
	somebody
Merge branch 'IB-12.34.567' of http://someurl/repos/somerepo into IB-12.34.567
{code}

If the branch name seems to follow a jira key pattern bamboo wrongly identifies it as a jira ticket, setting the underlink, trying to communicate with jira looking for details on this in-existing ticket, etc. In the case above bamboo would identify IB-12 as a jira ticket.

Bamboo should be able to let configure which strings patterns are not to be taken as jira tickets.
fields.summary: Improve the algorithm used to detect JIRA issue keys

fields.description:

fields.description:
Hi there

In Bamboo, it would be great if the reporting default filters have an option of 'Per sprint' or 'Last 2 weeks'. Currently they have 'Last 7 days' and 'Last 30 days' and you can select a range, but we are trying to automate this process reporting and most agile software development teams work in 2 or 3 week cycles iteration or sprints so we need the ability to be reporting on these periods specifically.

Thanks for your time :)

MYOB QA
fields.summary: Build reporting for JIRA Agile sprints

fields.summary: Custom script for build process suddenly stopped working

fields.description:
All variables are currently stored in the database with no encryption (Exceptions are repository passwords and Bamboo passwords [which are irreversibly hashed/salted]).

ex. : Deployment variables that contain passwords are stored in the database with no encryption. So anyone with access to the database schemas will be able to view all the sensitive passwords that are setup for deployment projects in Bamboo.

Please provide an option to encrypt all variables and store an encrypted version of them as this can be a major security concern for many users.
fields.summary: Encrypt password variables

fields.description:
Currently, we have separate deployment plans for product subsystems. These must be able to be built and released independently to QA, and so this works well.

However, for production releases, they must all be released in a specific order. Bamboo doesn't offer a way to do such orchestration.

This ticket is a request to add an orchestration component to Bamboo, that, for example, would allow us to pick and choose which deployments should run from what plans in what order to what environments. Essentially, we should be able to assemble multiple deployments (and trigger multiple deployment plans) into one "release execution plan" in order to orchestrate a release.

Thanks
fields.summary: Support multi tier/component deployments
